title: Learn Python in Less than 10 Minutes for Beginners (Fast & Easy)

Creating challenge file for student practice

data.title: Variables and Print Statements Practice
data.description: Practice creating variables and using print statements with string operations
data.concept_learned: Variable assignment, string concatenation, and print function usage

difficulty_levels.easy: Create a variable 'my_fruit' with value 'Grape' and print it
difficulty_levels.medium: Create two fruit variables and print them in one sentence using concatenation
difficulty_levels.hard: Create a list of 3 fruits and print each with a custom message

hints: print() function displays output to console

data.context: Running Python script to execute the code and see output
Running Python script to execute the code and see output
Creating challenge file for data types and type conversion practice

data.title: Data Types and Type Conversion Challenge
data.description: Practice working with different data types (integers, strings) and type conversion using str()
data.concept_learned: Integer variables, string variables, type conversion with str(), and string concatenation with mixed data types

difficulty_levels.easy: Create an integer variable 'age' with value 25 and a string variable 'person' with value 'Alice'. Print them together using str() conversion.
difficulty_levels.medium: Create variables for your birth year (integer), favorite color (string), and lucky number (integer). Print a sentence combining all three using proper type conversion.
difficulty_levels.hard: Create a mini profile: name (string), age (integer), height in cm (integer), and favorite foods (list). Print a formatted profile description using type conversion and concatenation.

hints: Use str() to convert integers to strings for concatenation
Remember that you cannot directly concatenate strings and integers
The + operator works for string concatenation after conversion
validation_criteria: successful use of str() for type conversion
working string concatenation with mixed types

data.code_to_add:
addition = a + b
difference = a - b
multiply = b * b
divide = a/b
power = a**b

data.context: Running Python script to execute the code and see output

data.code_to_add:
elif age == 18:
    print('You are getting old!')

data.context: Running Python script to execute the code and see output
Creating challenge file for conditional statements practice

data.title: Conditional Statements Challenge
data.description: Practice using if, elif, and else statements with comparison operators to create decision-making logic
data.concept_learned: Conditional statements (if/elif/else), comparison operators (>, ==, <), boolean values, and program flow control

difficulty_levels.easy: Create a variable 'score' with value 85. Write an if-else statement that prints 'Pass' if score is 60 or higher, otherwise print 'Fail'.
difficulty_levels.medium: Create a variable 'temperature' with value 75. Write if-elif-else statements for: if temp > 80 print 'Hot', if temp > 60 print 'Warm', if temp > 40 print 'Cool', else print 'Cold'.
difficulty_levels.hard: Create variables for 'grade' (integer 0-100) and 'attendance' (boolean). Write conditional logic that determines if a student gets: 'A' (grade >= 90 and attendance), 'B' (grade >= 80 and attendance), 'C' (grade >= 70), or 'F' (anything else).

hints: elif and else are optional - you can use just if
validation_criteria: correct if statement syntax with colon
logical flow from if to elif to else
